PS-NARRATIVE:

19450121-19891020 0.75

On July 16, 1948, Bulgaria and Hungary signed a mutual friendship pact. 

On September 8, 1948, Hungary and Bulgaria signed a trade agreement that provides for an exchange of Hungarian machinery, railway equipment, metals, electrical materials to Bulgaria in exchange for Bulgarian agricultural products, furs, vegetable seeds, and fruits. 

The Council for Mutual Economic Assistance, an economic alliance was established at an economic conference in Moscow, on January 5, 1949. Both countries were founding members. This organization aimed to increase economic cooperation and technological transfer between its members. 

On January 24, 1953, the two countries signed a new trade agreement increasing the amount of traded goods between the two countries. 

The Warsaw Pact, a military alliance between the Eastern European Communist states, including Czechoslovakia and East Germany, was established on May 14, 1955. The members pledged mutual defense in case a member was attacked.

During the 1956 Budapest Uprising, Bulgaria provided verbal support to Soviet Union's intervention in Hungary. 

On October 20, 1989 Hungary decided to give up Communism and turn to a multi-party system. Bulgaria did the same thing in June 1990. 

In the 1990s, the two countries were on the same path of membership to NATO and the European Union. They supported each other's memberships and cooperated in the OSCE, Council of Europe, and on issues related to navigation on the river Danube. 

Hungary joined NATO on March 12, 1999, while Bulgaria joined NATO on March 29, 2004. Hungary joined the EU on May 1, 2004, while Bulgaria joined the EU on January 1, 2007.
